1.verse: The Purpose of Proverbs - The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel:

2.verse: For learning what wisdom and discipline are; for understanding insightful sayings;

3.verse: for receiving wise instruction in righteousness, justice, and integrity;

4.verse: for teaching shrewdness to the inexperienced, knowledge and discretion to a young man—

5.verse: a wise man will listen and increase his learning, and a discerning man will obtain guidance—

6.verse: for understanding a proverb or a parable, the words of the wise, and their riddles.

7.verse: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and discipline.

8.verse: Avoid the Path of the Violent - Listen, my son, to your father’s instruction, and don’t reject your mother’s teaching,

9.verse: for they will be a garland of grace on your head and a gold chain around your neck.

10.verse: My son, if sinners entice you, don’t be persuaded.

11.verse: If they say—“Come with us! Let’s set an ambush and kill someone. Let’s attack some innocent person just for fun!

12.verse: Let’s swallow them alive, like Sheol, still healthy as they go down to the Pit.

13.verse: We’ll find all kinds of valuable property and fill our houses with plunder.

14.verse: Throw in your lot with us, and we’ll all share our money”—

15.verse: my son, don’t travel that road with them or set foot on their path,

16.verse: because their feet run toward trouble and they hurry to commit murder.

17.verse: It is foolish to spread a net where any bird can see it,

18.verse: but they set an ambush to kill themselves; they attack their own lives.

19.verse: Such are the paths of all who make profit dishonestly; it takes the lives of those who receive it.

20.verse: Wisdom’s Plea - Wisdom calls out in the street; she raises her voice in the public squares.

21.verse: She cries out above the commotion; she speaks at the entrance of the city gates:

22.verse: “How long, foolish ones, will you love ignorance? How long will you mockers enjoy mocking and you fools hate knowledge?

23.verse: If you respond to my warning, then I will pour out my spirit on you and teach you my words.

24.verse: Since I called out and you refused, extended my hand and no one paid attention,

25.verse: since you neglected all my counsel and did not accept my correction,

26.verse: I, in turn, will laugh at your calamity. I will mock when terror strikes you,

27.verse: when terror strikes you like a storm and your calamity comes like a whirlwind, when trouble and stress overcome you.

28.verse: Then they will call me, but I won’t answer; they will search for me, but won’t find me.

29.verse: Because they hated knowledge, didn’t choose to fear the LORD,

30.verse: were not interested in my counsel, and rejected all my correction,

31.verse: they will eat the fruit of their way and be glutted with their own schemes.

32.verse: For the turning away of the inexperienced will kill them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them.

33.verse: But whoever listens to me will live securely and be free from the fear of danger.”

1.verse: Wisdom’s Worth - My son, if you accept my words and store up my commands within you,

2.verse: listening closely to wisdom and directing your heart to understanding;

3.verse: furthermore, if you call out to insight and lift your voice to understanding,

4.verse: if you seek it like silver and search for it like hidden treasure,

5.verse: then you will understand the fear of the LORD and discover the knowledge of God.

6.verse: For the LORD gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding.

7.verse: He stores up success for the upright; He is a shield for those who live with integrity

8.verse: so that He may guard the paths of justice and protect the way of His loyal followers.

9.verse: Then you will understand righteousness, justice, and integrity—every good path.

10.verse: For wisdom will enter your mind, and knowledge will delight your heart.

11.verse: Discretion will watch over you, and understanding will guard you,

12.verse: rescuing you from the way of evil— from the one who says perverse things,

13.verse: from those who abandon the right paths to walk in ways of darkness,

14.verse: from those who enjoy doing evil and celebrate perversion,

15.verse: whose paths are crooked, and whose ways are devious.

16.verse: It will rescue you from a forbidden woman, from a stranger with her flattering talk,

17.verse: who abandons the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God;

18.verse: for her house sinks down to death and her ways to the land of the departed spirits.

19.verse: None return who go to her; none reach the paths of life.

20.verse: So follow the way of good people, and keep to the paths of the righteous.

21.verse: For the upright will inhabit the land, and those of integrity will remain in it;

22.verse: but the wicked will be cut off from the land, and the treacherous uprooted from it.

1.verse: Trust the LORD - My son, don’t forget my teaching, but let your heart keep my commands;

2.verse: for they will bring you many days, a full life, and well-being.

3.verse: Never let loyalty and faithfulness leave you. Tie them around your neck; write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.verse: Then you will find favor and high regard in the sight of God and man.

5.verse: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and do not rely on your own understanding;

6.verse: think about Him in all your ways, and He will guide you on the right paths.

7.verse: Don’t consider yourself to be wise; fear the LORD and turn away from evil.

8.verse: This will be healing for your body and strengthening for your bones.

9.verse: Honor the LORD with your possessions and with the first produce of your entire harvest;

10.verse: then your barns will be completely filled, and your vats will overflow with new wine.

11.verse: Do not despise the LORD’s instruction, my son, and do not loathe His discipline;

12.verse: for the LORD disciplines the one He loves, just as a father, the son he delights in.

13.verse: Wisdom Brings Happiness - Happy is a man who finds wisdom and who acquires understanding,

14.verse: for she is more profitable than silver, and her revenue is better than gold.

15.verse: She is more precious than jewels; nothing you desire compares with her.

16.verse: Long life is in her right hand; in her left, riches and honor.

17.verse: Her ways are pleasant, and all her paths, peaceful.

18.verse: She is a tree of life to those who embrace her, and those who hold on to her are happy.

19.verse: The LORD founded the earth by wisdom and established the heavens by understanding.

20.verse: By His knowledge the watery depths broke open, and the clouds dripped with dew.

21.verse: Maintain your competence and discretion. My son, don’t lose sight of them.

22.verse: They will be life for you and adornment for your neck.

23.verse: Then you will go safely on your way; your foot will not stumble.

24.verse: When you lie down, you will not be afraid; you will lie down, and your sleep will be pleasant.

25.verse: Don’t fear sudden danger or the ruin of the wicked when it comes,

26.verse: for the LORD will be your confidence and will keep your foot from a snare.

27.verse: Treat Others Fairly - When it is in your power, don’t withhold good from the one it belongs to.

28.verse: Don’t say to your neighbor, “Go away! Come back later. I’ll give it tomorrow”—when it is there with you.

29.verse: Don’t plan any harm against your neighbor, for he trusts you and lives near you.

30.verse: Don’t accuse anyone without cause, when he has done you no harm.

31.verse: Don’t envy a violent man or choose any of his ways;

32.verse: for the devious are detestable to the LORD, but He is a friend to the upright.

33.verse: The LORD’s curse is on the household of the wicked, but He blesses the home of the righteous;

34.verse: He mocks those who mock, but gives grace to the humble.

35.verse: The wise will inherit honor, but He holds up fools to dishonor.

1.verse: A Father’s Example - Listen, my sons, to a father’s discipline, and pay attention so that you may gain understanding,

2.verse: for I am giving you good instruction. Don’t abandon my teaching.

3.verse: When I was a son with my father, tender and precious to my mother,

4.verse: he taught me and said: “Your heart must hold on to my words. Keep my commands and live.

5.verse: Get wisdom, get understanding; don’t forget or turn away from the words of my mouth.

6.verse: Don’t abandon wisdom, and she will watch over you; love her, and she will guard you.

7.verse: Wisdom is supreme—so get wisdom. And whatever else you get, get understanding.

8.verse: Cherish her, and she will exalt you; if you embrace her, she will honor you.

9.verse: She will place a garland of grace on your head; she will give you a crown of beauty.”

10.verse: Two Ways of Life - Listen, my son. Accept my words, and you will live many years.

11.verse: I am teaching you the way of wisdom; I am guiding you on straight paths.

12.verse: When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; when you run, you will not stumble.

13.verse: Hold on to instruction; don’t let go. Guard it, for it is your life.

14.verse: Don’t set foot on the path of the wicked; don’t proceed in the way of evil ones.

15.verse: Avoid it; don’t travel on it. Turn away from it, and pass it by.

16.verse: For they can’t sleep unless they have done what is evil; they are robbed of sleep unless they make someone stumble.

17.verse: They eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.

18.verse: The path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, shining brighter and brighter until midday.

19.verse: But the way of the wicked is like the darkest gloom; they don’t know what makes them stumble.

20.verse: The Straight Path - My son, pay attention to my words; listen closely to my sayings.

21.verse: Don’t lose sight of them; keep them within your heart.

22.verse: For they are life to those who find them, and health to one’s whole body.

23.verse: Guard your heart above all else, for it is the source of life.

24.verse: Don’t let your mouth speak dishonestly, and don’t let your lips talk deviously.

25.verse: Let your eyes look forward; fix your gaze straight ahead.

26.verse: Carefully consider the path for your feet, and all your ways will be established.

27.verse: Don’t turn to the right or to the left; keep your feet away from evil.

1.verse: Avoid Seduction - My son, pay attention to my wisdom; listen closely to my understanding

2.verse: so that you may maintain discretion and your lips safeguard knowledge.

3.verse: Though the lips of the forbidden woman drip honey and her words are smoother than oil,

4.verse: in the end she’s as bitter as wormwood and as sharp as a double-edged sword.

5.verse: Her feet go down to death; her steps head straight for Sheol.

6.verse: She doesn’t consider the path of life; she doesn’t know that her ways are unstable.

7.verse: So now, my sons, listen to me, and don’t turn away from the words of my mouth.

8.verse: Keep your way far from her. Don’t go near the door of her house.

9.verse: Otherwise, you will give up your vitality to others and your years to someone cruel;

10.verse: strangers will drain your resources, and your earnings will end up in a foreigner’s house.

11.verse: At the end of your life, you will lament when your physical body has been consumed,

12.verse: and you will say, “How I hated discipline, and how my heart despised correction.

13.verse: I didn’t obey my teachers or listen closely to my mentors.

14.verse: I am on the verge of complete ruin before the entire community.”

15.verse: Enjoy Marriage - Drink water from your own cistern, water flowing from your own well.

16.verse: Should your springs flow in the streets, streams of water in the public squares?

17.verse: They should be for you alone and not for you to share with strangers.

18.verse: Let your fountain be blessed, and take pleasure in the wife of your youth.

19.verse: A loving doe, a graceful fawn— let her breasts always satisfy you; be lost in her love forever.

20.verse: Why, my son, would you be infatuated with a forbidden woman or embrace the breast of a stranger?

21.verse: For a man’s ways are before the LORD’s eyes, and He considers all his paths.

22.verse: A wicked man’s iniquities entrap him; he is entangled in the ropes of his own sin.

23.verse: He will die because there is no discipline, and be lost because of his great stupidity.

1.verse: Financial Entanglements - My son, if you have put up security for your neighbor or entered into an agreement with a stranger,

2.verse: you have been trapped by the words of your lips— ensnared by the words of your mouth.

3.verse: Do this, then, my son, and free yourself, for you have put yourself in your neighbor’s power: Go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.

4.verse: Don’t give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids.

5.verse: Escape like a gazelle from a hunter, like a bird from a fowler’s trap.

6.verse: Laziness - Go to the ant, you slacker! Observe its ways and become wise.

7.verse: Without leader, administrator, or ruler,

8.verse: it prepares its provisions in summer; it gathers its food during harvest.

9.verse: How long will you stay in bed, you slacker? When will you get up from your sleep?

10.verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest,

11.verse: and your poverty will come like a robber, your need, like a bandit.

12.verse: The Malicious Man - A worthless person, a wicked man goes around speaking dishonestly,

13.verse: winking his eyes, signaling with his feet, and gesturing with his fingers.

14.verse: He always plots evil with perversity in his heart— he stirs up trouble.

15.verse: Therefore calamity will strike him suddenly; he will be shattered instantly—beyond recovery.

16.verse: What the LORD Hates - The LORD hates six things; in fact, seven are detestable to Him:

17.verse: arrogant eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,

18.verse: a heart that plots wicked schemes, feet eager to run to evil,

19.verse: a lying witness who gives false testimony, and one who stirs up trouble among brothers.

20.verse: Warning against Adultery - My son, keep your father’s command, and don’t reject your mother’s teaching.

21.verse: Always bind them to your heart; tie them around your neck.

22.verse: When you walk here and there, they will guide you; when you lie down, they will watch over you; when you wake up, they will talk to you.

23.verse: For a command is a lamp, teaching is a light, and corrective discipline is the way to life.

24.verse: They will protect you from an evil woman, from the flattering tongue of a stranger.

25.verse: Don’t lust in your heart for her beauty or let her captivate you with her eyelashes.

26.verse: For a prostitute’s fee is only a loaf of bread, but an adulteress goes after a precious life.

27.verse: Can a man embrace fire and his clothes not be burned?

28.verse: Can a man walk on burning coals without scorching his feet?

29.verse: So it is with the one who sleeps with another man’s wife; no one who touches her will go unpunished.

30.verse: People don’t despise the thief if he steals to satisfy himself when he is hungry.

31.verse: Still, if caught, he must pay seven times as much; he must give up all the wealth in his house.

32.verse: The one who commits adultery lacks sense; whoever does so destroys himself.

33.verse: He will get a beating and dishonor, and his disgrace will never be removed.

34.verse: For jealousy enrages a husband, and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.

35.verse: He will not be appeased by anything or be persuaded by lavish gifts.

1.verse: My son, obey my words, and treasure my commands.

2.verse: Keep my commands and live; protect my teachings as the pupil of your eye.

3.verse: Tie them to your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.verse: Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and call understanding your relative.

5.verse: She will keep you from a forbidden woman, a stranger with her flattering talk.

6.verse: A Story of Seduction - At the window of my house I looked through my lattice.

7.verse: I saw among the inexperienced, I noticed among the youths, a young man lacking sense.

8.verse: Crossing the street near her corner, he strolled down the road to her house

9.verse: at twilight, in the evening, in the dark of the night.

10.verse: A woman came to meet him dressed like a prostitute, having a hidden agenda.

11.verse: She is loud and defiant; her feet do not stay at home.

12.verse: Now in the street, now in the squares, she lurks at every corner.

13.verse: She grabs him and kisses him; she brazenly says to him,

14.verse: “I’ve made fellowship offerings; today I’ve fulfilled my vows.

15.verse: So I came out to meet you, to search for you, and I’ve found you.

16.verse: I’ve spread coverings on my bed— richly colored linen from Egypt.

17.verse: I’ve perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

18.verse: Come, let’s drink deeply of lovemaking until morning. Let’s feast on each other’s love!

19.verse: My husband isn’t home; he went on a long journey.

20.verse: He took a bag of money with him and will come home at the time of the full moon.”

21.verse: She seduces him with her persistent pleading; she lures with her flattering talk.

22.verse: He follows her impulsively like an ox going to the slaughter, like a deer bounding toward a trap

23.verse: until an arrow pierces its liver, like a bird darting into a snare— he doesn’t know it will cost him his life.

24.verse: Now, my sons, listen to me, and pay attention to the words of my mouth.

25.verse: Don’t let your heart turn aside to her ways; don’t stray onto her paths.

26.verse: For she has brought many down to death; her victims are countless.

27.verse: Her house is the road to Sheol, descending to the chambers of death.

1.verse: Wisdom’s Appeal - Doesn’t Wisdom call out? Doesn’t Understanding make her voice heard?

2.verse: At the heights overlooking the road, at the crossroads, she takes her stand.

3.verse: Beside the gates at the entry to the city, at the main entrance, she cries out:

4.verse: “People, I call out to you; my cry is to mankind.

5.verse: Learn to be shrewd, you who are inexperienced; develop common sense, you who are foolish.

6.verse: Listen, for I speak of noble things, and what my lips say is right.

7.verse: For my mouth tells the truth, and wickedness is detestable to my lips.

8.verse: All the words of my mouth are righteous; none of them are deceptive or perverse.

9.verse: All of them are clear to the perceptive, and right to those who discover knowledge.

10.verse: Accept my instruction instead of silver, and knowledge rather than pure gold.

11.verse: For wisdom is better than jewels, and nothing desirable can compare with it.

12.verse: I, Wisdom, share a home with shrewdness and have knowledge and discretion.

13.verse: To fear the LORD is to hate evil. I hate arrogant pride, evil conduct, and perverse speech.

14.verse: I possess good advice and competence; I have understanding and strength.

15.verse: It is by me that kings reign and rulers enact just law;

16.verse: by me, princes lead, as do nobles and all righteous judges.

17.verse: I love those who love me, and those who search for me find me.

18.verse: With me are riches and honor, lasting wealth and righteousness.

19.verse: My fruit is better than solid gold, and my harvest than pure silver.

20.verse: I walk in the way of righteousness, along the paths of justice,

21.verse: giving wealth as an inheritance to those who love me, and filling their treasuries.

22.verse: “The LORD made me at the beginning of His creation, before His works of long ago.

23.verse: I was formed before ancient times, from the beginning, before the earth began.

24.verse: I was born when there were no watery depths and no springs filled with water.

25.verse: I was delivered before the mountains and hills were established,

26.verse: before He made the land, the fields, or the first soil on earth.

27.verse: I was there when He established the heavens, when He laid out the horizon on the surface of the ocean,

28.verse: when He placed the skies above, when the fountains of the ocean gushed out,

29.verse: when He set a limit for the sea so that the waters would not violate His command, when He laid out the foundations of the earth.

30.verse: I was a skilled craftsman beside Him. I was His delight every day, always rejoicing before Him.

31.verse: I was rejoicing in His inhabited world, delighting in the human race.

32.verse: “And now, my sons, listen to me; those who keep my ways are happy.

33.verse: Listen to instruction and be wise; don’t ignore it.

34.verse: Anyone who listens to me is happy, watching at my doors every day, waiting by the posts of my doorway.

35.verse: For the one who finds me finds life and obtains favor from the LORD,

36.verse: but the one who misses me harms himself; all who hate me love death.”

1.verse: Wisdom versus Foolishness - Wisdom has built her house; she has carved out her seven pillars.

2.verse: She has prepared her meat; she has mixed her wine; she has also set her table.

3.verse: She has sent out her female servants; she calls out from the highest points of the city:

4.verse: “Whoever is inexperienced, enter here!” To the one who lacks sense, she says,

5.verse: “Come, eat my bread, and drink the wine I have mixed.

6.verse: Leave inexperience behind, and you will live; pursue the way of understanding.

7.verse: The one who corrects a mocker will bring dishonor on himself; the one who rebukes a wicked man will get hurt.

8.verse: Don’t rebuke a mocker, or he will hate you; rebuke a wise man, and he will love you.

9.verse: Instruct a wise man, and he will be wiser still; teach a righteous man, and he will learn more.

10.verse: “The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.

11.verse: For by Wisdom your days will be many, and years will be added to your life.

12.verse: If you are wise, you are wise for your own benefit; if you mock, you alone will bear the consequences.”

13.verse: The woman Folly is rowdy; she is gullible and knows nothing.

14.verse: She sits by the doorway of her house, on a seat at the highest point of the city,

15.verse: calling to those who pass by, who go straight ahead on their paths:

16.verse: “Whoever is inexperienced, enter here!” To the one who lacks sense, she says,

17.verse: “Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten secretly is tasty!”

18.verse: But he doesn’t know that the departed spirits are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.

1.verse: A Collection of Solomon’s Proverbs - Solomon’s proverbs: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son, heartache to his mother.

2.verse: Ill-gotten gains do not profit anyone, but righteousness rescues from death.

3.verse: The LORD will not let the righteous go hungry, but He denies the wicked what they crave.

4.verse: Idle hands make one poor, but diligent hands bring riches.

5.verse: The son who gathers during summer is prudent; the son who sleeps during harvest is disgraceful.

6.verse: Blessings are on the head of the righteous, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

7.verse: The remembrance of the righteous is a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.

8.verse: A wise heart accepts commands, but foolish lips will be destroyed.

9.verse: The one who lives with integrity lives securely, but whoever perverts his ways will be found out.

10.verse: A sly wink of the eye causes grief, and foolish lips will be destroyed.

11.verse: The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

12.verse: Hatred stirs up conflicts, but love covers all offenses.

13.verse: Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning, but a rod is for the back of the one who lacks sense.

14.verse: The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of the fool hastens destruction.

15.verse: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city; the poverty of the poor is their destruction.

16.verse: The labor of the righteous leads to life; the activity of the wicked leads to sin.

17.verse: The one who follows instruction is on the path to life, but the one who rejects correction goes astray.

18.verse: The one who conceals hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.

19.verse: When there are many words, sin is unavoidable, but the one who controls his lips is wise.

20.verse: The tongue of the righteous is pure silver; the heart of the wicked is of little value.

21.verse: The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of sense.

22.verse: The LORD’s blessing enriches, and struggle adds nothing to it.

23.verse: As shameful conduct is pleasure for a fool, so wisdom is for a man of understanding.

24.verse: What the wicked dreads will come to him, but what the righteous desire will be given to them.

25.verse: When the whirlwind passes, the wicked are no more, but the righteous are secure forever.

26.verse: Like vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so the slacker is to the one who sends him on an errand.

27.verse: The fear of the LORD prolongs life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.

28.verse: The hope of the righteous is joy, but the expectation of the wicked comes to nothing.

29.verse: The way of the LORD is a stronghold for the honorable, but destruction awaits the malicious.

30.verse: The righteous will never be shaken, but the wicked will not remain on the earth.

31.verse: The mouth of the righteous produces wisdom, but a perverse tongue will be cut out.

32.verse: The lips of the righteous know what is appropriate, but the mouth of the wicked, only what is perverse.

1.verse: Dishonest scales are detestable to the LORD, but an accurate weight is His delight.

2.verse: When pride comes, disgrace follows, but with humility comes wisdom.

3.verse: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the perversity of the treacherous destroys them.

4.verse: Wealth is not profitable on a day of wrath, but righteousness rescues from death.

5.verse: The righteousness of the blameless clears his path, but the wicked person will fall because of his wickedness.

6.verse: The righteousness of the upright rescues them, but the treacherous are trapped by their own desires.

7.verse: When the wicked man dies, his expectation comes to nothing, and hope placed in wealth vanishes.

8.verse: The righteous one is rescued from trouble; in his place, the wicked one goes in.

9.verse: With his mouth the ungodly destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge the righteous are rescued.

10.verse: When the righteous thrive, a city rejoices, and when the wicked die, there is joyful shouting.

11.verse: A city is built up by the blessing of the upright, but it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.

12.verse: Whoever shows contempt for his neighbor lacks sense, but a man with understanding keeps silent.

13.verse: A gossip goes around revealing a secret, but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.

14.verse: Without guidance, people fall, but with many counselors there is deliverance.

15.verse: If someone puts up security for a stranger, he will suffer for it, but the one who hates such agreements is protected.

16.verse: A gracious woman gains honor, but violent men gain only riches.

17.verse: A kind man benefits himself, but a cruel man brings disaster on himself.

18.verse: The wicked man earns an empty wage, but the one who sows righteousness, a true reward.

19.verse: Genuine righteousness leads to life, but pursuing evil leads to death.

20.verse: Those with twisted minds are detestable to the LORD, but those with blameless conduct are His delight.

21.verse: Be assured that the wicked will not go unpunished, but the offspring of the righteous will escape.

22.verse: A beautiful woman who rejects good sense is like a gold ring in a pig’s snout.

23.verse: The desire of the righteous turns out well, but the hope of the wicked leads to wrath.

24.verse: One person gives freely, yet gains more; another withholds what is right, only to become poor.

25.verse: A generous person will be enriched, and the one who gives a drink of water will receive water.

26.verse: People will curse anyone who hoards grain, but a blessing will come to the one who sells it.

27.verse: The one who searches for what is good finds favor, but if someone looks for trouble, it will come to him.

28.verse: Anyone trusting in his riches will fall, but the righteous will flourish like foliage.

29.verse: The one who brings ruin on his household will inherit the wind, and a fool will be a slave to someone whose heart is wise.

30.verse: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, but violence takes lives.

31.verse: If the righteous will be repaid on earth, how much more the wicked and sinful.

1.verse: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but one who hates correction is stupid.

2.verse: The good person obtains favor from the LORD, but He condemns a man who schemes.

3.verse: Man cannot be made secure by wickedness, but the root of the righteous is immovable.

4.verse: A capable wife is her husband’s crown, but a wife who causes shame is like rottenness in his bones.

5.verse: The thoughts of the righteous are just, but guidance from the wicked leads to deceit.

6.verse: The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush, but the speech of the upright rescues them.

7.verse: The wicked are overthrown and perish, but the house of the righteous will stand.

8.verse: A man is praised for his insight, but a twisted mind is despised.

9.verse: Better to be dishonored, yet have a servant, than to act important but have no food.

10.verse: A righteous man cares about his animal’s health, but even the merciful acts of the wicked are cruel.

11.verse: The one who works his land will have plenty of food, but whoever chases fantasies lacks sense.

12.verse: The wicked desire what evil men have, but the root of the righteous produces fruit.

13.verse: An evil man is trapped by his rebellious speech, but a righteous one escapes from trouble.

14.verse: A man will be satisfied with good by the words of his mouth, and the work of a man’s hands will reward him.

15.verse: A fool’s way is right in his own eyes, but whoever listens to counsel is wise.

16.verse: A fool’s displeasure is known at once, but whoever ignores an insult is sensible.

17.verse: Whoever speaks the truth declares what is right, but a false witness, deceit.

18.verse: There is one who speaks rashly, like a piercing sword; but the tongue of the wise brings healing.

19.verse: Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue, only a moment.

20.verse: Deceit is in the hearts of those who plot evil, but those who promote peace have joy.

21.verse: No disaster overcomes the righteous, but the wicked are full of misery.

22.verse: Lying lips are detestable to the LORD, but faithful people are His delight.

23.verse: A shrewd person conceals knowledge, but a foolish heart publicizes stupidity.

24.verse: The diligent hand will rule, but laziness will lead to forced labor.

25.verse: Anxiety in a man’s heart weighs it down, but a good word cheers it up.

26.verse: A righteous man is careful in dealing with his neighbor, but the ways of the wicked lead them astray.

27.verse: A lazy man doesn’t roast his game, but to a diligent man, his wealth is precious.

28.verse: There is life in the path of righteousness, but another path leads to death.

1.verse: A wise son responds to his father’s discipline, but a mocker doesn’t listen to rebuke.

2.verse: From the words of his mouth, a man will enjoy good things, but treacherous people have an appetite for violence.

3.verse: The one who guards his mouth protects his life; the one who opens his lips invites his own ruin.

4.verse: The slacker craves, yet has nothing, but the diligent is fully satisfied.

5.verse: The righteous hate lying, but the wicked act disgustingly and disgracefully.

6.verse: Righteousness guards people of integrity, but wickedness undermines the sinner.

7.verse: One man pretends to be rich but has nothing; another pretends to be poor but has great wealth.

8.verse: Riches are a ransom for a man’s life, but a poor man hears no threat.

9.verse: The light of the righteous shines brightly, but the lamp of the wicked is put out.

10.verse: Arrogance leads to nothing but strife, but wisdom is gained by those who take advice.

11.verse: Wealth obtained by fraud will dwindle, but whoever earns it through labor will multiply it.

12.verse: Delayed hope makes the heart sick, but fulfilled desire is a tree of life.

13.verse: The one who has contempt for instruction will pay the penalty, but the one who respects a command will be rewarded.

14.verse: A wise man’s instruction is a fountain of life, turning people away from the snares of death.

15.verse: Good sense wins favor, but the way of the treacherous never changes.

16.verse: Every sensible person acts knowledgeably, but a fool displays his stupidity.

17.verse: A wicked messenger falls into trouble, but a trustworthy courier brings healing.

18.verse: Poverty and disgrace come to those who ignore discipline, but the one who accepts correction will be honored.

19.verse: Desire fulfilled is sweet to the taste, but to turn from evil is an abomination to fools.

20.verse: The one who walks with the wise will become wise, but a companion of fools will suffer harm.

21.verse: Disaster pursues sinners, but good rewards the righteous.

22.verse: A good man leaves an inheritance to his grandchildren, but the sinner’s wealth is stored up for the righteous.

23.verse: The uncultivated field of the poor yields abundant food, but without justice, it is swept away.

24.verse: The one who will not use the rod hates his son, but the one who loves him disciplines him diligently.

25.verse: A righteous man eats until he is satisfied, but the stomach of the wicked is empty.

1.verse: Every wise woman builds her house, but a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.

2.verse: Whoever lives with integrity fears the LORD, but the one who is devious in his ways despises Him.

3.verse: The proud speech of a fool brings a rod of discipline, but the lips of the wise protect them.

4.verse: Where there are no oxen, the feeding trough is empty, but an abundant harvest comes through the strength of an ox.

5.verse: An honest witness does not deceive, but a dishonest witness utters lies.

6.verse: A mocker seeks wisdom and doesn’t find it, but knowledge comes easily to the perceptive.

7.verse: Stay away from a foolish man; you will gain no knowledge from his speech.

8.verse: The sensible man’s wisdom is to consider his way, but the stupidity of fools deceives them.

9.verse: Fools mock at making restitution, but there is goodwill among the upright.

10.verse: The heart knows its own bitterness, and no outsider shares in its joy.

11.verse: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will stand.

12.verse: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.

13.verse: Even in laughter a heart may be sad, and joy may end in grief.

14.verse: The disloyal one will get what his conduct deserves, and a good man, what his deeds deserve.

15.verse: The inexperienced one believes anything, but the sensible one watches his steps.

16.verse: A wise man is cautious and turns from evil, but a fool is easily angered and is careless.

17.verse: A quick-tempered man acts foolishly, and a man who schemes is hated.

18.verse: The inexperienced inherit foolishness, but the sensible are crowned with knowledge.

19.verse: The evil bow before those who are good, the wicked, at the gates of the righteous.

20.verse: A poor man is hated even by his neighbor, but there are many who love the rich.

21.verse: The one who despises his neighbor sins, but whoever shows kindness to the poor will be happy.

22.verse: Don’t those who plan evil go astray? But those who plan good find loyalty and faithfulness.

23.verse: There is profit in all hard work, but endless talk leads only to poverty.

24.verse: The crown of the wise is their wealth, but the foolishness of fools produces foolishness.

25.verse: A truthful witness rescues lives, but one who utters lies is deceitful.

26.verse: In the fear of the LORD one has strong confidence and his children have a refuge.

27.verse: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, turning people away from the snares of death.

28.verse: A large population is a king’s splendor, but a shortage of people is a ruler’s devastation.

29.verse: A patient person shows great understanding, but a quick-tempered one promotes foolishness.

30.verse: A tranquil heart is life to the body, but jealousy is rottenness to the bones.

31.verse: The one who oppresses the poor person insults his Maker, but one who is kind to the needy honors Him.

32.verse: The wicked one is thrown down by his own sin, but the righteous one has a refuge in his death.

33.verse: Wisdom resides in the heart of the discerning; she is known even among fools.

34.verse: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.

35.verse: A king favors a wise servant, but his anger falls on a disgraceful one.

1.verse: A gentle answer turns away anger, but a harsh word stirs up wrath.

2.verse: The tongue of the wise makes knowledge attractive, but the mouth of fools blurts out foolishness.

3.verse: The eyes of the LORD are everywhere, observing the wicked and the good.

4.verse: The tongue that heals is a tree of life, but a devious tongue breaks the spirit.

5.verse: A fool despises his father’s discipline, but a person who accepts correction is sensible.

6.verse: The house of the righteous has great wealth, but trouble accompanies the income of the wicked.

7.verse: The lips of the wise broadcast knowledge, but not so the heart of fools.

8.verse: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is His delight.

9.verse: The LORD detests the way of the wicked, but He loves the one who pursues righteousness.

10.verse: Discipline is harsh for the one who leaves the path; the one who hates correction will die.

11.verse: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD— how much more, human hearts.

12.verse: A mocker doesn’t love one who corrects him; he will not consult the wise.

13.verse: A joyful heart makes a face cheerful, but a sad heart produces a broken spirit.

14.verse: A discerning mind seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.

15.verse: All the days of the oppressed are miserable, but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.

16.verse: Better a little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure with turmoil.

17.verse: Better a meal of vegetables where there is love than a fattened ox with hatred.

18.verse: A hot-tempered man stirs up conflict, but a man slow to anger calms strife.

19.verse: A slacker’s way is like a thorny hedge, but the path of the upright is a highway.

20.verse: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish man despises his mother.

21.verse: Foolishness brings joy to one without sense, but a man with understanding walks a straight path.

22.verse: Plans fail when there is no counsel, but with many advisers they succeed.

23.verse: A man takes joy in giving an answer; and a timely word—how good that is!

24.verse: For the discerning the path of life leads upward, so that he may avoid going down to Sheol.

25.verse: The LORD destroys the house of the proud, but He protects the widow’s territory.

26.verse: The LORD detests the plans of an evil man, but pleasant words are pure.

27.verse: The one who profits dishonestly troubles his household, but the one who hates bribes will live.

28.verse: The mind of the righteous person thinks before answering, but the mouth of the wicked blurts out evil things.

29.verse: The LORD is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.

30.verse: Bright eyes cheer the heart; good news strengthens the bones.

31.verse: One who listens to life-giving rebukes will be at home among the wise.

32.verse: Anyone who ignores discipline despises himself, but whoever listens to correction acquires good sense.

33.verse: The fear of the LORD is what wisdom teaches, and humility comes before honor.

1.verse: The reflections of the heart belong to man, but the answer of the tongue is from the LORD.

2.verse: All a man’s ways seem right to him, but the LORD evaluates the motives.

3.verse: Commit your activities to the LORD, and your plans will be achieved.

4.verse: The LORD has prepared everything for His purpose— even the wicked for the day of disaster.

5.verse: Everyone with a proud heart is detestable to the LORD; be assured, he will not go unpunished.

6.verse: Wickedness is atoned for by loyalty and faithfulness, and one turns from evil by the fear of the LORD.

7.verse: When a man’s ways please the LORD, He makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.

8.verse: Better a little with righteousness than great income with injustice.

9.verse: A man’s heart plans his way, but the LORD determines his steps.

10.verse: God’s verdict is on the lips of a king; his mouth should not give an unfair judgment.

11.verse: Honest balances and scales are the LORD’s; all the weights in the bag are His concern.

12.verse: Wicked behavior is detestable to kings, since a throne is established through righteousness.

13.verse: Righteous lips are a king’s delight, and he loves one who speaks honestly.

14.verse: A king’s fury is a messenger of death, but a wise man appeases it.

15.verse: When a king’s face lights up, there is life; his favor is like a cloud with spring rain.

16.verse: Get wisdom— how much better it is than gold! And get understanding— it is preferable to silver.

17.verse: The highway of the upright avoids evil; the one who guards his way protects his life.

18.verse: Pride comes before destruction, and an arrogant spirit before a fall.

19.verse: Better to be lowly of spirit with the humble than to divide plunder with the proud.

20.verse: The one who understands a matter finds success, and the one who trusts in the LORD will be happy.

21.verse: Anyone with a wise heart is called discerning, and pleasant speech increases learning.

22.verse: Insight is a fountain of life for its possessor, but the discipline of fools is folly.

23.verse: A wise heart instructs its mouth and increases learning with its speech.

24.verse: Pleasant words are a honeycomb: sweet to the taste and health to the body.

25.verse: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.

26.verse: A worker’s appetite works for him because his hunger urges him on.

27.verse: A worthless man digs up evil, and his speech is like a scorching fire.

28.verse: A contrary man spreads conflict, and a gossip separates close friends.

29.verse: A violent man lures his neighbor, leading him in a way that is not good.

30.verse: The one who narrows his eyes is planning deceptions; the one who compresses his lips brings about evil.

31.verse: Gray hair is a glorious crown; it is found in the way of righteousness.

32.verse: Patience is better than power, and controlling one’s temper, than capturing a city.

33.verse: The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the LORD.

1.verse: Better a dry crust with peace than a house full of feasting with strife.

2.verse: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son and share an inheritance among brothers.

3.verse: A crucible for silver, and a smelter for gold, and the LORD is the tester of hearts.

4.verse: A wicked person listens to malicious talk; a liar pays attention to a destructive tongue.

5.verse: The one who mocks the poor insults his Maker, and one who rejoices over calamity will not go unpunished.

6.verse: Grandchildren are the crown of the elderly, and the pride of sons is their fathers.

7.verse: Eloquent words are not appropriate on a fool’s lips; how much worse are lies for a ruler.

8.verse: A bribe seems like a magic stone to its owner; wherever he turns, he succeeds.

9.verse: Whoever conceals an offense promotes love, but whoever gossips about it separates friends.

10.verse: A rebuke cuts into a perceptive person more than a hundred lashes into a fool.

11.verse: An evil man seeks only rebellion; a cruel messenger will be sent against him.

12.verse: Better for a man to meet a bear robbed of her cubs than a fool in his foolishness.

13.verse: If anyone returns evil for good, evil will never depart from his house.

14.verse: To start a conflict is to release a flood; stop the dispute before it breaks out.

15.verse: Acquitting the guilty and condemning the just— both are detestable to the LORD.

16.verse: Why does a fool have money in his hand with no intention of buying wisdom?

17.verse: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for a difficult time.

18.verse: One without sense enters an agreement and puts up security for his friend.

19.verse: One who loves to offend loves strife; one who builds a high threshold invites injury.

20.verse: One with a twisted mind will not succeed, and one with deceitful speech will fall into ruin.

21.verse: A man fathers a fool to his own sorrow; the father of a fool has no joy.

22.verse: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a broken spirit dries up the bones.

23.verse: A wicked man secretly takes a bribe to subvert the course of justice.

24.verse: Wisdom is the focus of the perceptive, but a fool’s eyes roam to the ends of the earth.

25.verse: A foolish son is grief to his father and bitterness to the one who bore him.

26.verse: It is certainly not good to fine an innocent person or to beat a noble for his honesty.

27.verse: The intelligent person restrains his words, and one who keeps a cool head is a man of understanding.

28.verse: Even a fool is considered wise when he keeps silent, discerning when he seals his lips.

1.verse: One who isolates himself pursues selfish desires; he rebels against all sound judgment.

2.verse: A fool does not delight in understanding, but only wants to show off his opinions.

3.verse: When a wicked man comes, contempt also does, and along with dishonor, disgrace.

4.verse: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters, a flowing river, a fountain of wisdom.

5.verse: It is not good to show partiality to the guilty by perverting the justice due the innocent.

6.verse: A fool’s lips lead to strife, and his mouth provokes a beating.

7.verse: A fool’s mouth is his devastation, and his lips are a trap for his life.

8.verse: A gossip’s words are like choice food that goes down to one’s innermost being.

9.verse: The one who is truly lazy in his work is brother to a vandal.

10.verse: The name of Yahweh is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and are protected.

11.verse: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city; in his imagination it is like a high wall.

12.verse: Before his downfall a man’s heart is proud, but humility comes before honor.

13.verse: The one who gives an answer before he listens— this is foolishness and disgrace for him.

14.verse: A man’s spirit can endure sickness, but who can survive a broken spirit?

15.verse: The mind of the discerning acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks it.

16.verse: A gift opens doors for a man and brings him before the great.

17.verse: The first to state his case seems right until another comes and cross-examines him.

18.verse: Casting the lot ends quarrels and separates powerful opponents.

19.verse: An offended brother is harder to reach than a fortified city, and quarrels are like the bars of a fortress.

20.verse: From the fruit of his mouth a man’s stomach is satisfied; he is filled with the product of his lips.

21.verse: Life and death are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.

22.verse: A man who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.

23.verse: The poor man pleads, but the rich one answers roughly.

24.verse: A man with many friends may be harmed, but there is a friend who stays closer than a brother.

1.verse: Better a poor man who lives with integrity than someone who has deceitful lips and is a fool.

2.verse: Even zeal is not good without knowledge, and the one who acts hastily sins.

3.verse: A man’s own foolishness leads him astray, yet his heart rages against the LORD.

4.verse: Wealth attracts many friends, but a poor man is separated from his friend.

5.verse: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who utters lies will not escape.

6.verse: Many seek a ruler’s favor, and everyone is a friend of one who gives gifts.

7.verse: All the brothers of a poor man hate him; how much more do his friends keep their distance from him! He may pursue them with words, but they are not there.

8.verse: The one who acquires good sense loves himself; one who safeguards understanding finds success.

9.verse: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who utters lies perishes.

10.verse: Luxury is not appropriate for a fool— how much less for a slave to rule over princes!

11.verse: A person’s insight gives him patience, and his virtue is to overlook an offense.

12.verse: A king’s rage is like the roaring of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.

13.verse: A foolish son is his father’s ruin, and a wife’s nagging is an endless dripping.

14.verse: A house and wealth are inherited from fathers, but a sensible wife is from the LORD.

15.verse: Laziness induces deep sleep, and a lazy person will go hungry.

16.verse: The one who keeps commands preserves himself; one who disregards his ways will die.

17.verse: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD, and He will give a reward to the lender.

18.verse: Discipline your son while there is hope; don’t be intent on killing him.

19.verse: A person with great anger bears the penalty; if you rescue him, you’ll have to do it again.

20.verse: Listen to counsel and receive instruction so that you may be wise later in life.

21.verse: Many plans are in a man’s heart, but the LORD’s decree will prevail.

22.verse: What is desirable in a man is his fidelity; better to be a poor man than a liar.

23.verse: The fear of the LORD leads to life; one will sleep at night without danger.

24.verse: The slacker buries his hand in the bowl; he doesn’t even bring it back to his mouth.

25.verse: Strike a mocker, and the inexperienced learn a lesson; rebuke the discerning, and he gains knowledge.

26.verse: The one who assaults his father and evicts his mother is a disgraceful and shameful son.

27.verse: If you stop listening to correction, my son, you will stray from the words of knowledge.

28.verse: A worthless witness mocks justice, and a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.

29.verse: Judgments are prepared for mockers, and beatings for the backs of fools.

1.verse: Wine is a mocker, beer is a brawler, and whoever staggers because of them is not wise.

2.verse: A king’s terrible wrath is like the roaring of a lion; anyone who provokes him endangers himself.

3.verse: It is honorable for a man to resolve a dispute, but any fool can get himself into a quarrel.

4.verse: The slacker does not plow during planting season; at harvest time he looks, and there is nothing.

5.verse: Counsel in a man’s heart is deep water; but a man of understanding draws it out.

6.verse: Many a man proclaims his own loyalty, but who can find a trustworthy man?

7.verse: The one who lives with integrity is righteous; his children who come after him will be happy.

8.verse: A king sitting on a throne to judge sifts out all evil with his eyes.

9.verse: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am cleansed from my sin”?

10.verse: Differing weights and varying measures— both are detestable to the LORD.

11.verse: Even a young man is known by his actions— if his behavior is pure and upright.

12.verse: The hearing ear and the seeing eye— the LORD made them both.

13.verse: Don’t love sleep, or you will become poor; open your eyes, and you’ll have enough to eat.

14.verse: “It’s worthless, it’s worthless!” the buyer says, but after he is on his way, he gloats.

15.verse: There is gold and a multitude of jewels, but knowledgeable lips are a rare treasure.

16.verse: Take his garment, for he has put up security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for foreigners.

17.verse: Food gained by fraud is sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth is full of gravel.

18.verse: Finalize plans with counsel, and wage war with sound guidance.

19.verse: The one who reveals secrets is a constant gossip; avoid someone with a big mouth.

20.verse: Whoever curses his father or mother— his lamp will go out in deep darkness.

21.verse: An inheritance gained prematurely will not be blessed ultimately.

22.verse: Don’t say, “I will avenge this evil!” Wait on the LORD, and He will rescue you.

23.verse: Differing weights are detestable to the LORD, and dishonest scales are unfair.

24.verse: A man’s steps are determined by the LORD, so how can anyone understand his own way?

25.verse: It is a trap for anyone to dedicate something rashly and later to reconsider his vows.

26.verse: A wise king separates out the wicked and drives the threshing wheel over them.

27.verse: The LORD’s lamp sheds light on a person’s life, searching the innermost parts.

28.verse: Loyalty and faithfulness deliver a king; through loyalty he maintains his throne.

29.verse: The glory of young men is their strength, and the splendor of old men is gray hair.

30.verse: Lashes and wounds purge away evil, and beatings cleanse the innermost parts.

1.verse: A king’s heart is like streams of water in the LORD’s hand: He directs it wherever He chooses.

2.verse: All a man’s ways seem right to him, but the LORD evaluates the motives.

3.verse: Doing what is righteous and just is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.

4.verse: The lamp that guides the wicked— haughty eyes and an arrogant heart—is sin.

5.verse: The plans of the diligent certainly lead to profit, but anyone who is reckless certainly becomes poor.

6.verse: Making a fortune through a lying tongue is a vanishing mist, a pursuit of death.

7.verse: The violence of the wicked sweeps them away because they refuse to act justly.

8.verse: A guilty man’s conduct is crooked, but the behavior of the innocent is upright.

9.verse: Better to live on the corner of a roof than to share a house with a nagging wife.

10.verse: A wicked person desires evil; he has no consideration for his neighbor.

11.verse: When a mocker is punished, the inexperienced become wiser; when one teaches a wise man, he acquires knowledge.

12.verse: The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked; He brings the wicked to ruin.

13.verse: The one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will himself also call out and not be answered.

14.verse: A secret gift soothes anger, and a covert bribe, fierce rage.

15.verse: Justice executed is a joy to the righteous but a terror to those who practice iniquity.

16.verse: The man who strays from the way of wisdom will come to rest in the assembly of the departed spirits.

17.verse: The one who loves pleasure will become a poor man; whoever loves wine and oil will not get rich.

18.verse: The wicked are a ransom for the righteous, and the treacherous, for the upright.

19.verse: Better to live in a wilderness than with a nagging and hot-tempered wife.

20.verse: Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of a wise person, but a foolish man consumes them.

21.verse: The one who pursues righteousness and faithful love will find life, righteousness, and honor.

22.verse: A wise person went up against a city of warriors and brought down its secure fortress.

23.verse: The one who guards his mouth and tongue keeps himself out of trouble.

24.verse: The proud and arrogant person, named “Mocker,” acts with excessive pride.

25.verse: A slacker’s craving will kill him because his hands refuse to work.

26.verse: He is filled with craving all day long, but the righteous give and don’t hold back.

27.verse: The sacrifice of a wicked person is detestable— how much more so when he brings it with ulterior motives!

28.verse: A lying witness will perish, but the one who listens will speak successfully.

29.verse: A wicked man puts on a bold face, but the upright man considers his way.

30.verse: No wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel will prevail against the LORD.

31.verse: A horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory comes from the LORD.

1.verse: A good name is to be chosen over great wealth; favor is better than silver and gold.

2.verse: The rich and the poor have this in common: the LORD made them both.

3.verse: A sensible person sees danger and takes cover, but the inexperienced keep going and are punished.

4.verse: The result of humility is fear of the LORD, along with wealth, honor, and life.

5.verse: There are thorns and snares on the path of the crooked; the one who guards himself stays far from them.

6.verse: Teach a youth about the way he should go; even when he is old he will not depart from it.

7.verse: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is a slave to the lender.

8.verse: The one who sows injustice will reap disaster, and the rod of his fury will be destroyed.

9.verse: A generous person will be blessed, for he shares his food with the poor.

10.verse: Drive out a mocker, and conflict goes too; then quarreling and dishonor will cease.

11.verse: The one who loves a pure heart and gracious lips—the king is his friend.

12.verse: The LORD’s eyes keep watch over knowledge, but He overthrows the words of the treacherous.

13.verse: The slacker says, “There’s a lion outside! I’ll be killed in the public square!”

14.verse: The mouth of the forbidden woman is a deep pit; a man cursed by the LORD will fall into it.

15.verse: Foolishness is tangled up in the heart of a youth; the rod of discipline will drive it away from him.

16.verse: Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself, and giving to the rich—both lead only to poverty.

17.verse: Words of the Wise - Listen closely, pay attention to the words of the wise, and apply your mind to my knowledge.

18.verse: For it is pleasing if you keep them within you and if they are constantly on your lips.

19.verse: I have instructed you today—even you— so that your confidence may be in the LORD.

20.verse: Haven’t I written for you thirty sayings about counsel and knowledge,

21.verse: in order to teach you true and reliable words, so that you may give a dependable report to those who sent you?

22.verse: Don’t rob a poor man because he is poor, and don’t crush the oppressed at the gate,

23.verse: for the LORD will take up their case and will plunder those who plunder them.

24.verse: Don’t make friends with an angry man, and don’t be a companion of a hot-tempered man,

25.verse: or you will learn his ways and entangle yourself in a snare.

26.verse: Don’t be one of those who enter agreements, who put up security for loans.

27.verse: If you have no money to pay, even your bed will be taken from under you.

28.verse: Don’t move an ancient boundary marker that your fathers set up.

29.verse: Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will stand in the presence of kings. He will not stand in the presence of unknown men.

1.verse: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, consider carefully what is before you,

2.verse: and put a knife to your throat if you have a big appetite;

3.verse: don’t desire his choice food, for that food is deceptive.

4.verse: Don’t wear yourself out to get rich; stop giving your attention to it.

5.verse: As soon as your eyes fly to it, it disappears, for it makes wings for itself and flies like an eagle to the sky.

6.verse: Don’t eat a stingy person’s bread, and don’t desire his choice food,

7.verse: for it’s like someone calculating inwardly. “Eat and drink,” he says to you, but his heart is not with you.

8.verse: You will vomit the little you’ve eaten and waste your pleasant words.

9.verse: Don’t speak to a fool, for he will despise the insight of your words.

10.verse: Don’t move an ancient boundary marker, and don’t encroach on the fields of the fatherless,

11.verse: for their Redeemer is strong, and He will take up their case against you.

12.verse: Apply yourself to discipline and listen to words of knowledge.

13.verse: Don’t withhold discipline from a youth; if you beat him with a rod, he will not die.

14.verse: Strike him with a rod, and you will rescue his life from Sheol.

15.verse: My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will indeed rejoice.

16.verse: My innermost being will cheer when your lips say what is right.

17.verse: Don’t let your heart envy sinners; instead, always fear the LORD.

18.verse: For then you will have a future, and your hope will never fade.

19.verse: Listen, my son, and be wise; keep your mind on the right course.

20.verse: Don’t associate with those who drink too much wine or with those who gorge themselves on meat.

21.verse: For the drunkard and the glutton will become poor, and grogginess will clothe them in rags.

22.verse: Listen to your father who gave you life, and don’t despise your mother when she is old.

23.verse: Buy—and do not sell—truth, wisdom, instruction, and understanding.

24.verse: The father of a righteous son will rejoice greatly, and one who fathers a wise son will delight in him.

25.verse: Let your father and mother have joy, and let her who gave birth to you rejoice.

26.verse: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.

27.verse: For a prostitute is a deep pit, and a stranger is a narrow well;

28.verse: indeed, she sets an ambush like a robber and increases those among men who are unfaithful.

29.verse: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has conflicts? Who has complaints? Who has wounds for no reason? Who has red eyes?

30.verse: Those who linger over wine, those who go looking for mixed wine.

31.verse: Don’t gaze at wine because it is red, when it gleams in the cup and goes down smoothly.

32.verse: In the end it bites like a snake and stings like a viper.

33.verse: Your eyes will see strange things, and you will say absurd things.

34.verse: You’ll be like someone sleeping out at sea or lying down on the top of a ship’s mast.

35.verse: “They struck me, but I feel no pain! They beat me, but I didn’t know it! When will I wake up? I’ll look for another drink.”

1.verse: Don’t envy evil men or desire to be with them,

2.verse: for their hearts plan violence, and their words stir up trouble.

3.verse: A house is built by wisdom, and it is established by understanding;

4.verse: by knowledge the rooms are filled with every precious and beautiful treasure.

5.verse: A wise warrior is better than a strong one, and a man of knowledge than one of strength;

6.verse: for you should wage war with sound guidance— victory comes with many counselors.

7.verse: Wisdom is inaccessible to a fool; he does not open his mouth at the gate.

8.verse: The one who plots evil will be called a schemer.

9.verse: A foolish scheme is sin, and a mocker is detestable to people.

10.verse: If you do nothing in a difficult time, your strength is limited.

11.verse: Rescue those being taken off to death, and save those stumbling toward slaughter.

12.verse: If you say, “But we didn’t know about this,” won’t He who weighs hearts consider it? Won’t He who protects your life know? Won’t He repay a person according to his work?

13.verse: Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your palate;

14.verse: realize that wisdom is the same for you. If you find it, you will have a future, and your hope will never fade.

15.verse: Wicked man, don’t set an ambush, at the camp of the righteous man; don’t destroy his dwelling.

16.verse: Though a righteous man falls seven times, he will get up, but the wicked will stumble into ruin.

17.verse: Don’t gloat when your enemy falls, and don’t let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,

18.verse: or the LORD will see, be displeased, and turn His wrath away from him.

19.verse: Don’t be agitated by evildoers, and don’t envy the wicked.

20.verse: For the evil have no future; the lamp of the wicked will be put out.

21.verse: My son, fear the LORD, as well as the king, and don’t associate with rebels,

22.verse: for destruction from them will come suddenly; who knows what distress these two can bring?

23.verse: These sayings also belong to the wise: It is not good to show partiality in judgment.

24.verse: Whoever says to the guilty, “You are innocent”— people will curse him, and tribes will denounce him;

25.verse: but it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and a generous blessing will come to them.

26.verse: He who gives an honest answer gives a kiss on the lips.

27.verse: Complete your outdoor work, and prepare your field; afterward, build your house.

28.verse: Don’t testify against your neighbor without cause. Don’t deceive with your lips.

29.verse: Don’t say, “I’ll do to him what he did to me; I’ll repay the man for what he has done.”

30.verse: I went by the field of a slacker and by the vineyard of a man lacking sense.

31.verse: Thistles had come up everywhere, weeds covered the ground, and the stone wall was ruined.

32.verse: I saw, and took it to heart; I looked, and received instruction:

33.verse: a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest,

34.verse: and your poverty will come like a robber, your need, like a bandit.

1.verse: Hezekiah’s Collection - These too are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, copied.

2.verse: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter and the glory of kings to investigate a matter.

3.verse: As the heaven is high and the earth is deep, so the hearts of kings cannot be investigated.

4.verse: Remove impurities from silver, and a vessel will be produced for a silversmith.

5.verse: Remove the wicked from the king’s presence, and his throne will be established in righteousness.

6.verse: Don’t brag about yourself before the king, and don’t stand in the place of the great;

7.verse: for it is better for him to say to you, “Come up here!” than to demote you in plain view of a noble.

8.verse: Don’t take a matter to court hastily. Otherwise, what will you do afterward if your opponent humiliates you?

9.verse: Make your case with your opponent without revealing another’s secret;

10.verse: otherwise, the one who hears will disgrace you, and you’ll never live it down.

11.verse: A word spoken at the right time is like gold apples on a silver tray.

12.verse: A wise correction to a receptive ear is like a gold ring or an ornament of gold.

13.verse: To those who send him, a trustworthy messenger is like the coolness of snow on a harvest day; he refreshes the life of his masters.

14.verse: The man who boasts about a gift that does not exist is like clouds and wind without rain.

15.verse: A ruler can be persuaded through patience, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.

16.verse: If you find honey, eat only what you need; otherwise, you’ll get sick from it and vomit.

17.verse: Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s house; otherwise, he’ll get sick of you and hate you.

18.verse: A man giving false testimony against his neighbor is like a club, a sword, or a sharp arrow.

19.verse: Trusting an unreliable person in a difficult time is like a rotten tooth or a faltering foot.

20.verse: Singing songs to a troubled heart is like taking off clothing on a cold day or like pouring vinegar on soda.

21.verse: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;

22.verse: for you will heap burning coals on his head, and the LORD will reward you.

23.verse: The north wind produces rain, and a backbiting tongue, angry looks.

24.verse: Better to live on the corner of a roof than to share a house with a nagging wife.

25.verse: Good news from a distant land is like cold water to a parched throat.

26.verse: A righteous person who yields to the wicked is like a muddied spring or a polluted well.

27.verse: It is not good to eat too much honey or to seek glory after glory.

28.verse: A man who does not control his temper is like a city whose wall is broken down.

1.verse: Like snow in summer and rain at harvest, honor is inappropriate for a fool.

2.verse: Like a flitting sparrow or a fluttering swallow, an undeserved curse goes nowhere.

3.verse: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the backs of fools.

4.verse: Don’t answer a fool according to his foolishness or you’ll be like him yourself.

5.verse: Answer a fool according to his foolishness or he’ll become wise in his own eyes.

6.verse: The one who sends a message by a fool’s hand cuts off his own feet and drinks violence.

7.verse: A proverb in the mouth of a fool is like lame legs that hang limp.

8.verse: Giving honor to a fool is like binding a stone in a sling.

9.verse: A proverb in the mouth of a fool is like a stick with thorns, brandished by the hand of a drunkard.

10.verse: The one who hires a fool or who hires those passing by is like an archer who wounds everyone.

11.verse: As a dog returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his foolishness.

12.verse: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.verse: The slacker says, “There’s a lion in the road— a lion in the public square!”

14.verse: A door turns on its hinges, and a slacker, on his bed.

15.verse: The slacker buries his hand in the bowl; he is too weary to bring it to his mouth.

16.verse: In his own eyes, a slacker is wiser than seven men who can answer sensibly.

17.verse: A person who is passing by and meddles in a quarrel that’s not his is like one who grabs a dog by the ears.

18.verse: Like a madman who throws flaming darts and deadly arrows,

19.verse: so is the man who deceives his neighbor and says, “I was only joking!”

20.verse: Without wood, fire goes out; without a gossip, conflict dies down.

21.verse: As charcoal for embers and wood for fire, so is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.

22.verse: A gossip’s words are like choice food that goes down to one’s innermost being.

23.verse: Smooth lips with an evil heart are like glaze on an earthen vessel.

24.verse: A hateful person disguises himself with his speech and harbors deceit within.

25.verse: When he speaks graciously, don’t believe him, for there are seven abominations in his heart.

26.verse: Though his hatred is concealed by deception, his evil will be revealed in the assembly.

27.verse: The one who digs a pit will fall into it, and whoever rolls a stone— it will come back on him.

28.verse: A lying tongue hates those it crushes, and a flattering mouth causes ruin.

1.verse: Don’t boast about tomorrow, for you don’t know what a day might bring.

2.verse: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth— a stranger, and not your own lips.

3.verse: A stone is heavy and sand, a burden, but aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.

4.verse: Fury is cruel, and anger a flood, but who can withstand jealousy?

5.verse: Better an open reprimand than concealed love.

6.verse: The wounds of a friend are trustworthy, but the kisses of an enemy are excessive.

7.verse: A person who is full tramples on a honeycomb, but to a hungry person, any bitter thing is sweet.

8.verse: A man wandering from his home is like a bird wandering from its nest.

9.verse: Oil and incense bring joy to the heart, and the sweetness of a friend is better than self-counsel.

10.verse: Don’t abandon your friend or your father’s friend, and don’t go to your brother’s house in your time of calamity; better a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.

11.verse: Be wise, my son, and bring my heart joy, so that I can answer anyone who taunts me.

12.verse: A sensible person sees danger and takes cover; the inexperienced keep going and are punished.

13.verse: Take his garment, for he has put up security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for foreigners.

14.verse: If one blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, it will be counted as a curse to him.

15.verse: An endless dripping on a rainy day and a nagging wife are alike.

16.verse: The one who controls her controls the wind and grasps oil with his right hand.

17.verse: Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another.

18.verse: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and whoever looks after his master will be honored.

19.verse: As water reflects the face, so the heart reflects the person.

20.verse: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied, and people’s eyes are never satisfied.

21.verse: A crucible for silver, and a smelter for gold, and a man for the words of his praise.

22.verse: Though you grind a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with grain, you will not separate his foolishness from him.

23.verse: Know well the condition of your flock, and pay attention to your herds,

24.verse: for wealth is not forever; not even a crown lasts for all time.

25.verse: When hay is removed and new growth appears and the grain from the hills is gathered in,

26.verse: lambs will provide your clothing, and goats, the price of a field;

27.verse: there will be enough goat’s milk for your food— food for your household and nourishment for your female servants.

1.verse: The wicked flee when no one is pursuing them, but the righteous are as bold as a lion.

2.verse: When a land is in rebellion, it has many rulers, but with a discerning and knowledgeable person, it endures.

3.verse: A destitute leader who oppresses the poor is like a driving rain that leaves no food.

4.verse: Those who reject the law praise the wicked, but those who keep the law battle against them.

5.verse: Evil men do not understand justice, but those who seek the LORD understand everything.

6.verse: Better a poor man who lives with integrity than a rich man who distorts right and wrong.

7.verse: A discerning son keeps the law, but a companion of gluttons humiliates his father.

8.verse: Whoever increases his wealth through excessive interest collects it for one who is kind to the poor.

9.verse: Anyone who turns his ear away from hearing the law— even his prayer is detestable.

10.verse: The one who leads the upright into an evil way will fall into his own pit, but the blameless will inherit what is good.

11.verse: A rich man is wise in his own eyes, but a poor man who has discernment sees through him.

12.verse: When the righteous triumph, there is great rejoicing, but when the wicked come to power, people hide themselves.

13.verse: The one who conceals his sins will not prosper, but whoever confesses and renounces them will find mercy.

14.verse: Happy is the one who is always reverent, but one who hardens his heart falls into trouble.

15.verse: A wicked ruler over a helpless people is like a roaring lion or a charging bear.

16.verse: A leader who lacks understanding is very oppressive, but one who hates dishonest profit prolongs his life.

17.verse: A man burdened by bloodguilt will be a fugitive until death. Let no one help him.

18.verse: The one who lives with integrity will be helped, but one who distorts right and wrong will suddenly fall.

19.verse: The one who works his land will have plenty of food, but whoever chases fantasies will have his fill of poverty.

20.verse: A faithful man will have many blessings, but one in a hurry to get rich will not go unpunished.

21.verse: It is not good to show partiality— yet a man may sin for a piece of bread.

22.verse: A greedy man is in a hurry for wealth; he doesn’t know that poverty will come to him.

23.verse: One who rebukes a person will later find more favor than one who flatters with his tongue.

24.verse: The one who robs his father or mother and says, “That’s no sin,” is a companion to a man who destroys.

25.verse: A greedy person provokes conflict, but whoever trusts in the LORD will prosper.

26.verse: The one who trusts in himself is a fool, but one who walks in wisdom will be safe.

27.verse: The one who gives to the poor will not be in need, but one who turns his eyes away will receive many curses.

28.verse: When the wicked come to power, people hide, but when they are destroyed, the righteous flourish.

1.verse: One who becomes stiff-necked, after many reprimands will be shattered instantly— beyond recovery.

2.verse: When the righteous flourish, the people rejoice, but when the wicked rule, people groan.

3.verse: A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father, but one who consorts with prostitutes destroys his wealth.

4.verse: By justice a king brings stability to a land, but a man who demands “contributions” demolishes it.

5.verse: A man who flatters his neighbor spreads a net for his feet.

6.verse: An evil man is caught by sin, but the righteous one sings and rejoices.

7.verse: The righteous person knows the rights of the poor, but the wicked one does not understand these concerns.

8.verse: Mockers inflame a city, but the wise turn away anger.

9.verse: If a wise man goes to court with a fool, there will be ranting and raving but no resolution.

10.verse: Bloodthirsty men hate an honest person, but the upright care about him.

11.verse: A fool gives full vent to his anger, but a wise man holds it in check.

12.verse: If a ruler listens to lies, all his officials will be wicked.

13.verse: The poor and the oppressor have this in common: the LORD gives light to the eyes of both.

14.verse: A king who judges the poor with fairness— his throne will be established forever.

15.verse: A rod of correction imparts wisdom, but a youth left to himself is a disgrace to his mother.

16.verse: When the wicked increase, rebellion increases, but the righteous will see their downfall.

17.verse: Discipline your son, and it will bring you peace of mind and give you delight.

18.verse: Without revelation people run wild, but one who listens to instruction will be happy.

19.verse: A slave cannot be disciplined by words; though he understands, he doesn’t respond.

20.verse: Do you see a man who speaks too soon? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

21.verse: A slave pampered from his youth will become arrogant later on.

22.verse: An angry man stirs up conflict, and a hot-tempered man increases rebellion.

23.verse: A person’s pride will humble him, but a humble spirit will gain honor.

24.verse: To be a thief’s partner is to hate oneself; he hears the curse but will not testify.

25.verse: The fear of man is a snare, but the one who trusts in the LORD is protected.

26.verse: Many seek a ruler’s favor, but a man receives justice from the LORD.

27.verse: An unjust man is detestable to the righteous, and one whose way is upright is detestable to the wicked.

1.verse: The Words of Agur - The words of Agur son of Jakeh. The oracle. The man’s oration to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:

2.verse: I am more stupid than any other man, and I lack man’s ability to understand.

3.verse: I have not gained wisdom, and I have no knowledge of the Holy One.

4.verse: Who has gone up to heaven and come down? Who has gathered the wind in His hands? Who has bound up the waters in a cloak? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is His name, and what is the name of His Son— if you know?

5.verse: Every word of God is pure; He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.

6.verse: Don’t add to His words, or He will rebuke you, and you will be proved a liar.

7.verse: Two things I ask of You; don’t deny them to me before I die:
