8.verse: Keep falsehood and deceitful words far from me. Give me neither poverty nor wealth; feed me with the food I need.

9.verse: Otherwise, I might have too much and deny You, saying, “Who is the LORD?” or I might have nothing and steal, profaning the name of my God.

10.verse: Don’t slander a servant to his master or he will curse you, and you will become guilty.

11.verse: There is a generation that curses its father and does not bless its mother.

12.verse: There is a generation that is pure in its own eyes, yet is not washed from its filth.

13.verse: There is a generation—how haughty its eyes and pretentious its looks.

14.verse: There is a generation whose teeth are swords, whose fangs are knives, devouring the oppressed from the land and the needy from among mankind.

15.verse: The leech has two daughters: “Give, Give!” Three things are never satisfied; four never say, “Enough!”:

16.verse: Sheol; a childless womb; earth, which is never satisfied with water; and fire, which never says, “Enough!”

17.verse: As for the eye that ridicules a father and despises obedience to a mother, may ravens of the valley pluck it out and young vultures eat it.

18.verse: Three things are beyond me; four I can’t understand:

19.verse: the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship at sea, and the way of a man with a young woman.

20.verse: This is the way of an adulteress: she eats and wipes her mouth and says, “I’ve done nothing wrong.”

21.verse: The earth trembles under three things; it cannot bear up under four:

22.verse: a servant when he becomes king, a fool when he is stuffed with food,

23.verse: an unloved woman when she marries, and a servant girl when she ousts her queen.

24.verse: Four things on earth are small, yet they are extremely wise:

25.verse: the ants are not a strong people, yet they store up their food in the summer;

26.verse: hyraxes are not a mighty people, yet they make their homes in the cliffs;

27.verse: locusts have no king, yet all of them march in ranks;

28.verse: a lizard can be caught in your hands, yet it lives in kings’ palaces.

29.verse: Three things are stately in their stride, even four are stately in their walk:

30.verse: a lion, which is mightiest among beasts and doesn’t retreat before anything,

31.verse: a strutting rooster, a goat, and a king at the head of his army.

32.verse: If you have been foolish by exalting yourself or if you’ve been scheming, put your hand over your mouth.

33.verse: For the churning of milk produces butter, and twisting a nose draws blood, and stirring up anger produces strife.

1.verse: The Words of Lemuel - The words of King Lemuel, an oracle that his mother taught him:

2.verse: What should I say, my son? What, son of my womb? What, son of my vows?

3.verse: Don’t spend your energy on women or your efforts on those who destroy kings.

4.verse: It is not for kings, Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine or for rulers to desire beer.

5.verse: Otherwise, they will drink, forget what is decreed, and pervert justice for all the oppressed.

6.verse: Give beer to one who is dying and wine to one whose life is bitter.

7.verse: Let him drink so that he can forget his poverty and remember his trouble no more.

8.verse: Speak up for those who have no voice, for the justice of all who are dispossessed.

9.verse: Speak up, judge righteously, and defend the cause of the oppressed and needy.

10.verse: In Praise of a Capable Wife - Who can find a capable wife? She is far more precious than jewels.

11.verse: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will not lack anything good.

12.verse: She rewards him with good, not evil, all the days of her life.

13.verse: She selects wool and flax and works with willing hands.

14.verse: She is like the merchant ships, bringing her food from far away.

15.verse: She rises while it is still night and provides food for her household and portions for her female servants.

16.verse: She evaluates a field and buys it; she plants a vineyard with her earnings.

17.verse: She draws on her strength and reveals that her arms are strong.

18.verse: She sees that her profits are good, and her lamp never goes out at night.

19.verse: She extends her hands to the spinning staff, and her hands hold the spindle.

20.verse: Her hands reach out to the poor, and she extends her hands to the needy.

21.verse: She is not afraid for her household when it snows, for all in her household are doubly clothed.

22.verse: She makes her own bed coverings; her clothing is fine linen and purple.

23.verse: Her husband is known at the city gates, where he sits among the elders of the land.

24.verse: She makes and sells linen garments; she delivers belts to the merchants.

25.verse: Strength and honor are her clothing, and she can laugh at the time to come.

26.verse: She opens her mouth with wisdom and loving instruction is on her tongue.

27.verse: She watches over the activities of her household and is never idle.

28.verse: Her sons rise up and call her blessed. Her husband also praises her:

29.verse: “Many women are capable, but you surpass them all!”

30.verse: Charm is deceptive and beauty is fleeting, but a woman who fears the LORD will be praised.

31.verse: Give her the reward of her labor, and let her works praise her at the city gates.
